Posting on X, formerly known as Twitter, the NPAS said "If you think it's windy down there, spare a thought for us up here in our flying washing machine".

The footage was filmed near Lea Valley reservoirs, North London.

The storm, which was named by the Met Office on Wednesday, has caused widespread disruption across the country.

Gusts of up to 80mph (128km/h) have been recorded in some parts of the UK, with the worst affected areas being Wales, the Midlands and the north of England.

The Met Office has issued a yellow weather warning for wind, which is in place until 6pm on Thursday.

The warning covers most of England and Wales, as well as parts of Scotland.

The Met Office said: "Strong winds will continue to affect many parts of the UK through Thursday, with gusts of 50-60mph (80-96km/h) inland and around 70mph (112km/h) in exposed coastal areas.

"There is also a risk of some disruption to transport and power supplies, as well as some damage to trees and buildings."

The Environment Agency has issued a flood alert for parts of the River Severn in Worcestershire, due to the high winds and heavy rainfall.

The agency said: "Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible.

"Be prepared to act on your flood plan. Do not walk, cycle or drive through flood water.

"We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message as the situation changes."

The Met Office has also issued a snow and ice warning for parts of Scotland, which is in place until 11am on Thursday.

The warning covers the Highlands and Grampian regions, where up to 10cm (4in) of snow is possible in some areas.
